questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to intermittent fevers and chills over the past few days. Last week, she underwent routine dental cleaning. The patient has a history of mitral valve prolapse. Temperature is 38.2 C (100.8 F). Physical examination reveals a non-ejection mid-systolic click followed by a late-systolic murmur best heard at the cardiac apex. Blood cultures are drawn and grow gram-positive bacteria that synthesize dextrans from sucrose. Which of the following is the likely cause?
questions.solution: Ans. A. S. viridans

  3. Right-left movement is by atlanto-axial joint
  4. Tibialis anterior has parallel oriented fibres
questions.solution: Ans. D. 3

questions.text: A 6-year-old, previously healthy girl is brought to the OPD due to diarrhea and abdominal pain. The patient started having watery diarrhea after going out to BBQ Nation for a meal with family; her stools became grossly bloody 2 days later. Her mother also had similar symptoms. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F). The abdomen is soft with mild, generalized tenderness. Stool culture performed on sorbitol-MacConkey agar shows sorbitol-negative colonies. Which of the following bacteria produces a toxin that is most like the one detected in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Shigella dysenteriae

choices.text: It is example of pressure epiphysis.
It gives attachment to long head of humerus and coracobrachialis.
It is palpable in delto-pectoral groove.
Gives insertion to pectoralis major muscle

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the marked structure is accurate?
questions.solution: Ans. C. It is palpable in delto-pectoral groove.

choices.text: TMP-SMX, Fluconazole, Azithromycin

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a skin rash on his left lower extremity. A month ago, the patient noticed several purple spots on his left calf that have progressively enlarged but are not painful or pruritic.  HIV testing is positive, CD4 count is 45/mm³, and HIV viral load is45,000 copies/mL. In addition to antiretroviral therapy and treatment of the skin lesions, which of the following is recommended for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. TMP-SMX only

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the physician due to diarrhea for the last 4 months. He visited a student health clinic at his university a month ago and was prescribed a course of antibiotics, but his diarrhea failed to improve. He also has persistent nausea, a bloating sensation, and a 6.8-kg weight loss. Microscopic examination of his stool is shown in the image. Impairment of which of the following immune functions would most likely predispose to this patient's infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secretory IgA production

 

  • The stool image shows Giardia lamblia cyst.
  • Clinical history: chronic diarrhea, bloating, weight loss, non-response to antibiotics → consistent with giardiasis.
  • Giardia infects the small intestine, attaching to the mucosa and causing malabsorption and steatorrhea.
  • Immune defense:
    • The main protective mechanism is secretory IgA in the intestinal mucosa.
    • IgA prevents adherence of Giardia to the mucosal surface.
  • Patients with IgA deficiency or conditions impairing mucosal immunity (eg, X-linked agammaglobulinemia) are predisposed to chronic/recurrent giardiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial killing by neutrophils: Important for pyogenic bacterial infections, not for protozoa like Giardia.

 

Option B. CD8+ T lymphocyte-mediated cytotoxicity: Crucial for viral infections and intracellular pathogens[like T. whipplei, not Giardia (which is extracellular).

 

Option C. Eosinophil-mediated cytotoxicity: Important in helminthic (worm) infections, not protozoan Giardia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN type of lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Subacute combined degeneration of cord

questions.text: 42-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a week of fever, sore throat, malaise, headache, and skin rash. The rash began on his trunk a week ago and has now spread to his entire body. He has had no chest pain, shortness of breath, diarrhea, or urethral discharge. He has had 3 new female sexual partners over the last year. He drinks alcohol occasionally but does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Examination shows a full-body maculopapular rash without evidence of excoriations. Several raised, grey mucosal patches are seen in the mouth. Cervical, axillary, inguinal, and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Syphilis

choices.text: A-anterior cerebral artery, B-ICA, C-infundibulum, D-Posterior communicating artery, E-III nerve, F-IV nerve
A-anterior communicating artery, B-ICA, C-Infundibulum, D-posterior communicating artery, E-III nerve, F- IV nerve
A-anterior cerebral artery, B-ICA, C-Infundibulum, D-posterior communicating artery, E-IV nerve, F- V nerve
A-anterior communicating artery, B-ICA, C-Infundibulum, D-posterior communicating artery, E-III nerve, F- V nerve

questions.solution: Ans. B) A-anterior communicating artery, B-ICA, C-Infundibulum, D-posterior communicating artery, E-III nerve, F- IV nerve

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Ans. A. A-4, B-3, C-5, D-2

questions.text: Loss of sensation to root of penis could be a result of injury to which of the following nerve?
questions.solution: Ans. B. B.

questions.text: All of the following structures lie in the relation to the left ureter except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Quadratus lumborum

 

The ureter descends from the renal pelvis to the bladder, and along its course, it has important anatomical relations. Quadratus lumborum is more lateral in position, and the ureter lies directly on the psoas major, not quadratus lumborum. Hence, quadratus lumborum is not in relation to the ureter.

 

Relations of the left ureter:

 

  • Posteriorly (lumbar part): Psoas major, bifurcation of common iliac artery.
  • Medially: Inferior mesenteric vessels, sigmoid colon & its mesentery, sigmoidal veins.
  • Anteriorly: Left colic vessels, left testicular/ovarian vessels, root of sigmoid mesocolon.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a week of fever, dyspnea, and cough with productive, foul-smelling sputum. She underwent an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy 10 days ago for a long history of heartburn. Temperature is 38.7 C°(101.7°F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 108/min, and respirations are 22/min. Dentition is poor. Crackles are heard over the right upper lung field. Complete blood count shows leukocytes of 14,500/mm'. Chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following additional therapies would be most helpful for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clindamycin

 

  • Clinical clues:
    • Recent upper GI endoscopy → risk of aspiration.
    • Poor dentition → anaerobic oral flora colonization.
    • Symptoms: foul-smelling sputum, fever, productive cough, dyspnea.
    • Chest X-ray: consolidation with possible abscess in the right upper lobe (common aspiration site in supine patients).
  • Diagnosis: Aspiration pneumonia with anaerobic lung abscess.
  • Best antibiotic: Clindamycin, because it covers:
    • Anaerobes (Bacteroides, Fusobacterium, Peptostreptococcus).
    • Oral flora (Streptococcus viridans).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ampicillin and gentamicin: Good for Enterococcus and gram-negatives, but poor anaerobic coverage.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: Mainly for gram-negative rods, poor anaerobic and oral flora coverage.

 

Option D. Doxycycline: Broad-spectrum antibiotic, but not reliable for anaerobes in aspiration pneumonia.

choices.text: Dorsal scapular nerve
From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.text: A 42-year-old male present to the OPD complaining of chronic neck pain and stiffness. The pain is localized on the back and side of the neck and sometimes radiates to the shoulder. Pain is particularly exacerbated by rotating the head to the opposite side and tilting it downwards. Marked muscles is most likely involved in this patient's condition. What is the nerve supply of this muscle?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Dorsal scapular nerve

questions.solution: Ans. A. Liquid paraffin- Hot air oven

questions.text: A hospital wants to estimate the prevalence of diabetic nephropathy. Kidney biopsy samples are obtained from 500 adult patients with diabetes who receive care at the hospital. The samples are then interpreted by 10 different pathologists, 5 of whom work at the hospital and 5 of whom work at nearby institutions. A preliminary analysis shows that the pathologists who work for the hospital are 3 times more likely to interpret the biopsy samples as diabetic nephropathy compared to those who do not work for the hospital. Which of the following most likely explains this difference in interpretation?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Observer bias

questions.text: Which of the following muscle groups is primarily assessed with this test to check for motor function in the hand?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Dorsal interossei

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to fatty food intolerance. On examination, her vital signs are normal, and she has mild right upper quadrant abdominal tenderness. An ultrasonogram of the abdomen reveals multiple gallstones with no evidence of cholecystitis and an ill-defined intrahepatic cyst with a thick wall. A CT of the abdomen is performed and is shown below. What is the most likely etiology for the intrahepatic cyst in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Hydatid cyst

Identify the true statements:

 

  1. IVC passes through the central tendon of diaphragm

  4. Superficial anterior compartment of leg has no neurovascular bundle
questions.solution: Ans. A. 1,3

questions.text:
Which of the following terms best describes the MacConkey medium?

 

  1. Differential
  2. Enrichment
  3. Transport
  4. Selective
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

MacConkey agar is both differential and selective:

 

Statement 1. Differential:

 

  • Contains lactose and neutral red (pH indicator).
  • Lactose fermenters (eg, E. coli, Klebsiella) → produce pink colonies.
  • Non-lactose fermenters (eg, Salmonella, Shigella, Pseudomonas) → produce colorless colonies.

 

Statement 4. Selective:

 

  • Contains bile salts and crystal violet, which inhibit the growth of gram-positive bacteria.
  • Allows only gram-negative organisms to grow.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. Enrichment medium: Used to enhance growth of fastidious organisms (eg, blood agar, chocolate agar).

 

Statement 3. Transport medium: Used to preserve specimens during transport (eg, Stuart’s, Amies medium). Not the function of MacConkey agar.

questions.text: 25-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a painless ulcer on his penis. He is unwilling to disclose sexual history. Physical examination shows a shallow, nontender, and nonexudative penile ulcer with a smooth base. Mild bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Serum rapid plasma reagin is positive, and HIV testing is negative.  The patient previously required hospitalization in the intensive care unit for a severe rash and oropharyngeal swelling after taking penicillin for a sore throat. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Oral doxycycline

questions.text:
Identify the synovial joints:

 

  1. Costotransverse joint

  2. Costovertebral joint

  3. Costo-chondral joints

  4. 2nd Sternocostal joint

  5. Sternoclavicular joint
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Synovial joints → freely movable joints with a synovial cavity, synovial membrane, articular cartilage, and joint capsule.

 

Statement 1. Costotransverse joint: Synovial (plane type) between tubercle of rib and transverse process of vertebra. 

 

Statement 2. Costovertebral joint: Synovial (plane type) between head of rib and body of vertebrae. 

 

Statement 3. Costo-chondral joints: Primary cartilaginous joints (synchondroses) between rib and its costal cartilage. 

 

Statement 5. Sternoclavicular joint: Synovial (saddle type) with an articular disc. 

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 4. 2nd Sternocostal joint: Synovial (plane type) → exception, as 1st sternocostal is primary cartilaginous.

questions.text:
Identify the false statements:

 

  1. Rickettsial morula in a monocyte is diagnostic of Ehrlichia chaffeensis
  2. E6, E7 are targets of vaccine against HPV
  3. SARS CO-2 specimen handling for molecular testing needs BSL-2
  4. Raynold-Braude phenomenon is seen in C. albicans
questions.solution: Ans. C. 2

choices.text: Reduced R-time, increased angle, increased MA, increased LY30
Prolonged R-time, decreased angle, decreased MA, decreased LY30
Prolonged R-time, decreased angle, decreased MA, increased LY30
Reduced R-time, decreased angle, increased MA, decreased LY30

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with sepsis and purpura fulminans. Thromboelastography (TEG) is ordered to assess the patient's clotting profile. Which of the following TEG tracings is most consistent with the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolonged R-time, decreased angle, decreased MA, increased LY30

 

  • The patient with sepsis and purpura fulminans is likely experiencing disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  • In DIC, thromboelastography (TEG) typically shows:
    • Prolonged R-time: due to coagulation factor consumption leading to delayed clot initiation.
    • Increased angle: fibrinolysis may initially cause rapid clot formation before consumption.
    • Decreased maximum amplitude (MA): due to platelet dysfunction or decreased platelet count.
    • Increased LY30: indicating increased fibrinolysis and clot breakdown.

 

Other tracings do not fit the complex coagulopathy seen in sepsis-induced DIC with purpura fulminans.

Zonula occludens toxin
ADP-ribosylation of EF2

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the bacterium whose biochemical tests are shown in the figure below?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Increase in cAMP

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the OPDdue to joint pain. Her symptoms began 10 days ago and consist of bilateral pain in the metacarpophalangeal joints, proximal interphalangeal joints, wrists, knees, and ankles. She describes joint stiffness lasting 10-15 minutes on awakening in the morning. The patient has also had associated fatigue and a few episodes of loose bowel movements associated with mild skin itching and patchy redness. She has no fever, weight loss, or lymphadenopathy.  She works as an elementary school teacher. On examination, there is tenderness of the involved joints without swelling or redness. Which of the following is most likely elevated in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Anti-parvovirus B19 IgM antibodies

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

questions.text: Which among the following is incorrect regarding Sibsons's fascia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

 

Sibson’s fascia (also called the suprapleural membrane) is a specialized thickening of the endothoracic fascia at the thoracic inlet.

 

  • Attachments:
    • Laterally → inner border of 1st rib & its costal cartilage (not 2nd rib).
    • Medially → tip of transverse process of C7 vertebra.
  • Relations[Other Options:]
    • Covers the apex of the lung and cervical pleura, preventing bulging into the root of the neck.
    • Considered a derivative of the scalenus minimus muscle (when present).
    • Subclavian vessels and branches of brachial plexus pass above the fascia.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Thelarche is the first sign of puberty in females.
  2. Maximum growth occurs in Tanner stages 4 and 5 in males
  3. Penile enlargement is the first sign of puberty in males
  4. Peak growth velocity always precedes menarche in females
questions.solution: Ans. A. 1,2,4

questions.text: Identify the structure that represents all 3 types of white matter?
questions.solution: Ans. D. D

questions.text: The anesthetist feels a snap while performing an epidural catheter insertion. All of the layers are punctured except:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Dura mater

choices.text: Abnormal protein in an infected animal brain
Infectious oocysts in feline feces
Neurotropic virus acquired from an infected animal bite
Parasite eggs in contaminated food or water

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He is an agricultural scientist and recently spent 3 months with rural pig farmers. Temperature is 36.8 C (98.2 F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 86/min. Electroencephalogram shows epileptiform activity. MRI of the brain is shown. A rapid HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Parasite eggs in contaminated food or water

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patients presents with hemiplegia on right side of body. On examination he was having loss of proprioception, fine touch and vibration sensations on right side. He was also unable to recognize the objects with closed eyes from right hand. On examination left side of the tongue was atrophied and deviation on left side during protrusion was found. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dejerine’s syndrome

 

The clinical features point to medial medullary involvement:

 

  1. Hemiplegia on right side → due to involvement of pyramidal tract (corticospinal fibers) in the medulla.
  2. Loss of proprioception, vibration, fine touch (right side) → due to lesion of medial lemniscus.
  3. Atrophy + deviation of tongue to left (ipsilateral) → due to involvement of hypoglossal nerve/nucleus (CN XII).

 

This classic triad = Dejerine’s syndrome (medial medullary syndrome).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parinaud’s syndrome:

 

  • Midbrain lesion (pineal tumor, dorsal midbrain).
  • Features: vertical gaze palsy, light-near dissociation of pupils, convergence-retraction nystagmus.
  • Not consistent with findings here.

 

Option B. Raymond’s syndrome:

 

  • Lesion in pons (ventral).
  • Causes contralateral hemiplegia + ipsilateral abducens (CN VI) palsy.
  • Tongue involvement (CN XII) is not seen.

 

Option D. Wallenberg’s syndrome (Lateral medullary syndrome):

 

  • Due to PICA occlusion.
  • Features: ipsilateral loss of pain/temp on face, contralateral pain/temp loss on body, ataxia, dysphagia, Horner’s syndrome.

  2. Common carotid artery divides at the level of lower border of thyroid cartilage
  3. Dermis has dense irregular connective tissue

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a week of persistent dry cough that disturbs his sleep. He has also had a sore throat, headaches, and fatigue. Yesterday, he noticed a rash on his arms and legs. Temperature is 37.8 C (100 F), blood pressure is 115/78 mm Hg, pulse is 86/min, and respirations are 16/min. Mild pharyngeal erythema is present. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. A faint macular rash is present on the extremities. Chest x-ray reveals increased interstitial markings and a small right-sided pleural effusion. Which of the following organisms is most likely causing this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Mycoplasma pneumoniae

questions.text: A seventeen-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department having just ingested a large overdose of an antihistaminic drug. This drug is a weak base capable of entering most tissues including the brain. Which of the following statements is true:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NH4Cl, an acidifying agent.

choices.text: Single dose of Tdap vaccine
Tetanus immune globulin and tetanus toxoid vaccine

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department after stepping on a nail that punctured his right sole while jogging at a park. He brought the nail, which is about 4 cm long and rusty, with him. He received a  3-dose primary tetanus vaccination series in childhood but has not received any booster doses since then.  Physical examination shows a puncture wound at the middle of the right plantar area with some dry blood and tenderness. Radiographs of the right foot reveal no bony injury or foreign body. The wound is cleaned with iodine solution. Which of the following additional interventions for tetanus prevention is most appropriate in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Tetanus immune globulin and tetanus toxoid vaccine

questions.text: Identify the muscle which is affected in locked jaw:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Lateral pterygoid

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to a week of fever, chills, productive cough with yellow-white sputum, and shortness of breath. The patient received an allogenic renal transplantation 6 months ago and currently takes maintenance immunosuppressive therapy. Chest imaging is shown below. Sputum Gram stain and culture are negative. Bronchoalveolar lavage cultures yield light growth of branching, filamentous rods that are partially acid-fast. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nocardiosis

 

  • Patient history:
    • Renal transplant → immunosuppressed.
    • Fever, productive cough, dyspnea with negative Gram stain and culture.
    • CT chest: multiple cavitary lung lesions with consolidation.
  • Bronchoalveolar lavage findings: branching filamentous rods that are partially acid-fast → classic for Nocardia species.
  • Nocardia is an aerobic, gram-positive, weakly acid-fast, branching filamentous bacterium.
  • Common presentation: pulmonary nocardiosis (cavitary pneumonia) in immunocompromised hosts, which may disseminate to the brain and skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB (Mycobacterium tuberculosis): Also causes cavitary lung disease, but organisms are fully acid-fast bacilli, not branching filamentous rods.

 

Option C. Histoplasma:

 

  • Dimorphic fungus, not filamentous branching rods.
  • Associated with Ohio & Mississippi river valleys, and shows yeast in macrophages, not acid-fast filaments.

 

Option D. Mucormycosis

 

  • Broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae on biopsy.
  • Causes rhino-orbital-cerebral disease in diabetics and immunosuppressed, not partially acid-fast rods.

questions.text: The test shown below, which uses a bacitracin disk, is useful in identifying:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptococcus pyogenes

 

  • The image shows a bacitracin sensitivity test on a blood agar plate.
  • A paper disk impregnated with bacitracin (disk A) is placed on the agar.
  • Zone of inhibition around the bacitracin disk = organism is sensitive.
  • Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus):
    • Beta-hemolytic on blood agar.
    • Characteristically bacitracin sensitive → used as a key lab test for identification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: Beta-hemolytic on blood agar, but identification relies on catalase test (positive) and coagulase test (positive).

 

Option C. Clostridium botulinum: Anaerobic spore-forming bacillus; identified using Nagler reaction.

 

Option D. Bacillus: Large gram-positive rods; usually identified by spore staining and other biochemical tests[eg-McFayden’s reaction], not bacitracin sensitivity.

questions.text: Identify the liver segment star marked in the image below:
questions.solution: Ans. A. V

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the urgent care clinic with a penile lesion that appeared a week ago as a painful papule and has since changed and worsened. Genital examination reveals a tender, 1.5-cm ulcer on the prepuce with well-demarcated, undermined borders and a purulent exudate. Two smaller ulcers with a similar appearance are near the larger ulcer. He has no penile discharge and the scrotum appears normal. Several inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged and tender. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's penile ulcer?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Haemophilus ducreyi infection

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department in the afternoon due to the sudden onset of abdominal cramps, nausea, and 6 or 7 episodes of vomiting over the past 3 hours. He has had no diarrhea or fever. Yesterday, the patient went on a day-long hike in a nearby forest and had dinner at a Chinese restaurant with friends. Today, he reheated some of the leftover noodles and rice for lunch. None of his friends developed similar symptoms Temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min. The abdomen is soft and nontender with no organomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Ingestion of preformed enterotoxin in the food

questions.text: 1st pharyngeal arch gives rise to all except:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Levator veli palatini

questions.text: 28-year-old man comes to the office due to abnormal movements of his arm and face over the last week. The patient has had 1- to 2-minute episodes of jerking and twitching of the left arm and left side of the faceThe patient was recently diagnosed with HIV and started antiretroviral therapy 2 months ago. At that time, his CD4 count was 46./mm3. Temperature is 37.8 C (100 F), blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 76/min. Left arm motor strength is 4/5, and deep tendon reflexes are 3+. An MRI of the brain is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine

choices.text: Loss of taste sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue
Loss of taste sensation from posterior 1/3 tongue
Loss of general sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue
Loss of taste sensation from posterior most part of tongue

questions.text: Injury to the nerve that passes through structure marked A will result in?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Loss of taste sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue

questions.text: During surgery on a 56-year-old man for a squamous cell carcinoma of the neck, the surgeon notices profuse bleeding from the deep cervical artery. Which of the following arteries must be ligated immediately to stop bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Costocervical trunk

 

  • The deep cervical artery is a branch of the costocervical trunk, which arises from the second part of the subclavian artery (posterior to the anterior scalene).
  • In case of profuse bleeding from the deep cervical artery, the surgeon must ligate the costocervical trunk to control it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior thyroid artery:

 

  • Branch of the thyrocervical trunk.
  • Supplies thyroid gland and related structures.
  • Not related to the deep cervical artery.

Option B. Transverse cervical artery:

 

  • Also a branch of the thyrocervical trunk.
  • Supplies trapezius and posterior scapular region.
  • Not the source of the deep cervical artery.

 

Option C. Thyrocervical trunk:

 

  • Branch of the first part of subclavian artery.
  • Gives rise to inferior thyroid, transverse cervical, suprascapular arteries.
  • Does not give deep cervical artery.

questions.text: Human herpesvirus 8 is associated with all except?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Adult T-cell leukemia

choices.text: Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days
Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days
Right umbilical vein gives rise to ligamentum teres
Functional closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 days

questions.text: The true statement about fetal circulation is:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to 1 day of painful swelling of the left side of her face, associated with high fever and chills. She has had no facial trauma or injury to that area. Physical examination shows a warm, tender, erythematous rash with raised, well-demarcated borders on the left side of the face, including the left external ear. The ear canal has no discharge, and hearing is intact. Mild regional lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism of this patient's infection?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Group A Streptococcus

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reflex, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

It is mandibular nerve (V3) passing through the foramen ovale. Diagnosis is Trigeminal neuralgia (tic douloureux) involving the mandibular division (V3).

 

  • Hemifacial pain on clenching teeth points to involvement of V3, which carries sensory fibers from the lower face/teeth and motor fibers to the muscles of mastication (clenching aggravates pain).
  • Normal pupillary, light, and accommodation reflexes make cranial nerves II, III, and the parasympathetic pathway to the eye unlikely.
  • Lacrimation may be reflex/associated autonomic accompaniment of trigeminal pain and does not require ocular parasympathetic involvement to be abnormal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1. (Optic nerve): Involved in light reflex 

 

Option B. 2. (Abducens nerve): muscle for eye movement.

 

Option D. 4. (Facial nerve): supplies facial muscles.

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below does not give rise to which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Ligamentum teres

choices.text: Double-stranded DNA → double-stranded DNA template → double-stranded DNA progeny
Double-stranded DNA → +RNA template → partially double-stranded DNA progeny
Single-stranded DNA → double-stranded DNA template → single-stranded DNA progeny
Single-stranded +RNA → double-stranded DNA template → single-stranded +RNA progeny

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man comes to the OPD due to 2 months of fatigue, intermittent arthralgias, and poor appetite. Liver aminotransferases are elevated. Hepatitis serology shows the following.

 

Hepatitis A virus antibody, total: negative

 

Hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb): negative

 

Hepatitis B core antibody (HBcAb), total: positive

 

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg): positive

 

Hepatitis B E antigen (HBeAg): positive

 

Hepatitis C virus antibody: negative

 

Which of the following genome replicative processes is most likely used by the virus infecting this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Double-stranded DNA → +RNA template → partially double-stranded DNA progeny.

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle, proceeding from the medial to the lateral direction.

 

  1. General somatic
  2. General visceral
  3. Special somatic
  4. Special visceral
questions.solution: Ans. B) 2, 4, 1, 3

choices.text: Endoscopy with biopsy, cytology, and culture

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a week of pain with swallowing and a substernal burning sensation. The patient was diagnosed with HIV 2 years ago. He was previously noncompliant with treatment but recently started taking antiretroviral therapy and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. CD4 count a month ago was 46/mm3.Examination of the oral cavity shows white plaques on the buccal mucosa and palate that are easily removable with a tongue scraper. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nontender. What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's substernal chest pain?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Oral fluconazole

choices.text: Paralysis of the right genioglossus muscle permitted the left genioglossus to pull the tongue forward and turned the tip to the right side.
Genioglossus originates from the lower genial tubercles of the mandible
The hypoglossal nerve descends in the neck between the internal carotid artery and the internal jugular vein.

At about the level of the tip of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone the hypoglossal nerve turns forward and crosses the internal and external carotid arteries and the lingual artery to enter the tongue

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the trauma centre with a stab wound on the right side of the neck just lateral to the tip of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone. During the physical examination the patient was asked to protrude his tongue, which deviated to the right. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Genioglossus originates from the lower genial tubercles of the mandible

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with poorly controlled diabetes presents with respiratory distress and copious nasal discharge since last 3 weeks. HRCT is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Mucor spp.

questions.text: The life cycle given below is of which of the following:
questions.solution: Ans. D. E. Histolytica

choices.text: Right superior gluteal nerve palsy
Left superior gluteal nerve palsy
Right inferior gluteal nerve palsy

questions.text: Patient had difficulty in walking upstairs. When he was made to bear weight on right lower limb, the left-sided pelvis dropped down but when he was standing on the left lower limb, the right-sided pelvis moved up. Which of the following is the likely lesion?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Right superior gluteal nerve palsy

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to 18 hours of headache and lethargy. The headache began last night after she returned from a camping trip with her friends during which she had been healthy. The patient had fever and vomiting overnight, and this morning her family had difficulty waking her. Temperature is 39.6 C (103.3 F), blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 22/min. The patient is obtunded and responds only to deep, painful stimuli. Physical examination shows resistance to passive neck flexion and several petechiae on the lower extremities. Cerebrospinal fluid test results are as follows:

 

Glucose: 20 mg/dL

 

Protein: 475 mg/dL


TLC: 2000/mm3


Neutrophils: 90%


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Meningococcus

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Circumvallate

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Incubation period of LGV is 10-30days
  2. Mycobacterium indicus pranii (MIP) was indigenously developed in India for use in malaria.
  3. C.parvum is the most common coccidian parasite to be causing diarhhea in HIV/AIDS.
  4. Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in U797 phosphotransferase
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

Statement 1. Incubation period of LGV is 10–30 days:

 

  • Correct
  • Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1–L3.
  • Incubation period: 10–30 days before inguinal lymphadenitis and buboes appear.

 

Statement 2. Mycobacterium indicus pranii (MIP) was indigenously developed in India for use in malaria:

 

  • Incorrect.
  • MIP was developed in India as an immunomodulatory vaccine against leprosy and tuberculosis, not malaria.

 

Statement 3. Cryptosporidium parvum is the most common coccidian parasite causing diarrhea in HIV/AIDS:

 

  • Incorrect.
  • The most common coccidian parasite in HIV/AIDS patients with chronic diarrhea is Isospora belli, although Cryptosporidium can also cause severe diarrhea.
  • In many textbooks, Isospora is emphasized as the commonest.

 

Statement 4. Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase:

 

  • Correct.
  • CMV resistance to ganciclovir arises from mutation in UL97 gene, which encodes a viral phosphotransferase needed to phosphorylate ganciclovir for activation.

choices.text: Ability to decompose hydrogen peroxide
Gamma hemolysis on blood agar
Growth only in absence of oxygen

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD due to 2 days of dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency. He recently underwent a cystoscopy for evaluation of hematuria. The patient has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and 30 pack-years of cigarette smoking. His temperature is 38.2 C (100.8 F). On examination, there is suprapubic tenderness on deep palpation but no costovertebral angle tenderness. Midstream urine culture grows gram-positive cocci in chains with growth > 100,000 colony-forming units/mL. The organism responsible for this patient's condition is most likely to demonstrate which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Gamma hemolysis on blood agar

choices.text: Superficial peroneal nerve

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with difficulty in foot eversion and sensory loss on the lateral leg & dorsum of foot. Which nerve lesion will lead to the following condition:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Superficial peroneal nerve

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a 3-week history of fever, weight loss, and anorexia. Both blood cultures grow Streptococcus gallolyticus. Echocardiogram reveals vegetations on the mitral valve. Other than antibiotic treatment, what additional step is recommended in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Colonoscopy

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which nerve is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Musculocutaneous nerve

questions.text: Identify the organism?
questions.solution: Ans. A. P. falciparum

questions.text:
Identify the true statements:

 

  1. Prevotella is a strict anaerobe
  2. Babesiosis may be seen in hepatocytes
  3. Interferon beta is raised in viral infections
  4. Affinity maturation is due to isotype switching
questions.solution: Ans. D. 1,3

questions.text: All the following form the marked structure except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2nd Palmar interossei

 

The marked structure in the image is the extensor expansion (dorsal digital expansion/extensor hood) of the finger.

 

It is formed by:

 

  • Extensor digitorum
  • Lumbricals
  • Dorsal interossei (including 2nd)
    but not by the 2nd palmar interossei (which is absent on the middle finger)

choices.text: Bacterial inoculation from a reservoir cat
Dimorphic fungus from decaying vegetation
Filarial larvae transmitted by mosquito bite

questions.text: 38-year-old man comes to the OPD due to 2 weeks of mildly pruritic and uncomfortable skin lesions. He first noticed a papule on his right index finger that soon ulcerated and began draining an odorless discharge. He then developed similar nodules on his right forearm. He works as a landscaper and recently began living with his girlfriend, who owns a cat. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Dimorphic fungus from decaying vegetation

questions.text: Which nerve injury is most likely responsible for the observed symptoms of foot?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Common peroneal nerve

 

The image shows "foot drop," where the affected foot cannot be dorsiflexed and appears to hang limp. This is most commonly caused by injury to the common peroneal (fibular) nerve, which innervates the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion and toe extension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Femoral nerve: Injury leads to weakness of knee extension (quadriceps) and sensory loss over the anterior thigh and medial leg, not foot drop.

 

Option C. Sciatic nerve: Injury produces loss of all functions below the knee (including foot drop), plus loss of plantar flexion and knee flexion. There would be a more flaccid, overall paralyzed lower limb.

 

Option D. Tibial nerve: Injury causes loss of plantar flexion and inversion of the foot, resulting in dorsiflexed/"calcaneovalgus" foot, not foot drop.

choices.text: Between the internal oblique and external oblique
Between the internal oblique and rectus abdominis
Between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.text: The neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies in?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.text: Third part of vertebral artery is related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2

 

The third part of the vertebral artery is related to the posterior arch of Atlas, which is marked as 2 in the image.

 

  • The vertebral artery's third part runs in a groove on the superior surface of the posterior arch of Atlas (C1), before entering the foramen magnum.

questions.text: Solvent/Detergent (SD) plasma destroys lipid-enveloped viruses. So, on SD plasma transfusion, which of the following infection is likely to occur?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Hepatitis A Virus (HAV)

questions.text: 22-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 12 weeks gestation comes to the OPD due to 3 days of rash, fever, and malaise. The rash seems to be getting larger but does not hurt or itch. Two weeks ago, the patient went camping. Temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 16/min. The rash is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Amoxicillin

questions.text:
Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery?

 

  1. Superior gluteal artery
  2. Inferior gluteal artery
  3. Superior vesical artery
  4. Middle rectal artery
  5. Inferior vesical artery
  6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution: Ans. C. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

choices.text: Present medial to white rami communicantes

questions.text: All of the following are true about grey rami communicantes except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preganglionic

 

Grey rami contain postganglionic, not preganglionic, fibers.

 

Rami communicantes are connections between the spinal nerves and the sympathetic chain.

 

  • White rami communicantes
    • Contain preganglionic sympathetic fibers (myelinated).
    • Present only at T1–L2 spinal levels (thoracolumbar outflow).
  • Grey rami communicantes
    • Contain postganglionic sympathetic fibers (unmyelinated).
    • Present at all spinal levels, because sympathetic supply must reach the entire body.
    • They connect the sympathetic ganglia back to the spinal nerves.
    • Usually lie medial to white rami.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unmyelinated: True. Grey rami carry postganglionic unmyelinated fibers.

 

Option B. Connected to spinal nerve: True. They rejoin the spinal nerve to distribute sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D. Present medial to white rami communicantes: True in relation to sympathetic chain.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong regarding primary and secondary immune response?
questions.solution: Ans. D. 4

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Leptospira

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a week of fever, chills, dyspnea on exertion, nonproductive cough, and fatigue. The patient has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and was diagnosed with lupus nephritis by renal biopsy 4 months ago. She started taking cyclophosphamide and prednisone 40 mg daily, which have stabilized her renal function.

 

Pulse oximetry is 86% on room air. The patient is using accessory muscles to breathe. No jugular venous distension is present. Cardiopulmonary examination shows bilateral crackles and normal heart sounds.  Laboratory results are as follows

 

Complete blood count

 

Leukocytes: 12,400/mm³

 

Arterial blood gases

 

pH: 7.48

 

PaO2: 60 mm Hg

 

PaCO2: 29 mm Hg

 

Lactate dehydrogenase: 340 U/L

 

Chest x-ray reveals bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C. PCP

questions.text: Which is not a branch of the vessel known as the Anesthetist’s artery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mental

 

The anesthetist’s artery refers to the facial artery, an important branch of the external carotid artery. It is clinically significant because of its use in anesthesia and its tortuous course around the face. 

 

The Mental artery is not a branch of the facial artery. It is a terminal branch of the inferior alveolar artery (from maxillary artery), which exits the mental foramen to supply the chin and lower lip.

 

Branches of the facial artery (extracranial part):

 

  • Cervical branches: Ascending palatine, tonsillar, submental, glandular branches.
  • Facial branches:
    • Inferior labial artery
    • Superior labial artery
    • Lateral nasal artery
    • Angular artery (terminal branch)

questions.text: Which artery can be palpated by gently pressing your fingers between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal (Achilles) tendon?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Posterior tibial artery

questions.text: Special electrodes are used to detect the change in membrane potential of a specific type of cardiac cell. These changes are recorded on the graph below. The deflection indicated by the arrow is most likely caused by movement of which of the following ions?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Calcium

questions.text: The blood oxygen saturations measured from different fetal vessel samples are 71%, 64%, 62%, 55%, and 43%. The sample with the greatest oxygen saturation was most likely obtained from which of the following blood vessels?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior vena cava

 

In the fetus, oxygenation occurs in the placenta, not the lungs. Oxygen-rich blood returns via the umbilical vein (≈80% saturation). This blood partially bypasses the liver through the ductus venosus and joins the inferior vena cava (IVC), which therefore carries the highest oxygen saturation (around 70–75%).

 

Oxygen saturation in various fetal vessels:

 

  • Umbilical vein → ~80% (highest, but not in options here).
  • Inferior vena cava (just above ductus venosus entry) → ~70–75%.
  • Right atrium (mixed) → ~62–65%.
  • Pulmonary trunk → ~55–60%.[option D]
  • Ductus arteriosus → ~55–60%.[option B]
  • Descending aorta (distal) → ~45–55%.[option A]

questions.text:
A 22-year-old student comes to the physician complaining of 4 days of fever, double vision, and painful swelling around his eyes. He also has significant muscle pain in his neck and jaw muscles. Two weeks ago the patient returned from a trip to Goa. One week after his return, he developed abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. These symptoms resolved spontaneously. He has a history of intravenous drug abuse but recently completed a drug rehabilitation program. His temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 14/min. Physical examination shows subungual splinter hemorrhages, periorbital edema, and chemosis. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs. The abdomen is soft and nontender without organomegaly. Laboratory results are as follows: 

Mean corpuscular volume: 13.0 g/dL

Platelets: 228,000/mm³

Leukocytes: 10,500/mm³

Neutrophils: 56%

Eosinophils: 22%

Lymphocytes: 23% 

Creatine kinase: 220 U/L

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichinellosis

 

  • History & exposure: Returned from Goa → likely consumed undercooked pork (common source of Trichinella spiralis).
  • Clinical course:
    • Initial GI symptoms: abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea → due to intestinal phase of infection.
    • Followed by systemic phase: fever, myalgias, periorbital edema, chemosis, and eosinophilia due to muscle invasion by larvae.
    • Subungual splinter hemorrhages can also be seen in trichinellosis (though classic in endocarditis).
  • Labs:
    • Marked eosinophilia (22%).
    • Mild CK elevation → muscle involvement.
  • All of these point to trichinellosis.
  • The following image shows histology of Trichinellosis in a muscle tissue.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascariasis: May cause eosinophilia but usually presents with intestinal obstruction or pulmonary migration symptoms (Löffler’s syndrome), not periorbital edema or myositis.

 

Option B. Dengue fever:

 

  • Presents with fever, myalgia (“breakbone fever”), rash, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.
  • Eosinophilia is not seen; instead, platelets drop, which is normal here.

 

Option D. Infective endocarditis:

 

  • Splinter hemorrhages may suggest this, but there’s no murmur, no bacteremia history, no valve findings.
  • Eosinophilia and periorbital edema do not fit.

questions.text: The structure marked in the image is embedded in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral head of gastrocnemius

 

The structure marked by the arrow in the image is the fabella, a sesamoid bone found in the tendon of the lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle behind the knee.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial head of gastrocnemius: This is the muscle on the inner side of the calf; the fabella is never embedded here.

 

Option C. Popliteal artery: This vessel runs behind the knee joint, deep to the gastrocnemius muscle. It is continuation of Femoral Artery.

 

Option D. Adductor longus: A muscle of the medial thigh compartment, unrelated to Fabella.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with fever and weight loss. He gives a history of blood in the stools and vomiting 2 weeks ago. On examination, there is right hypochondriac tenderness and hepatomegaly. Abdominal CT a lesion in the right lobe of the liver with ragged edges, multiple septations, and  eterogenous densities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Amoebic liver abscess

questions.text: A 25-year-old male went for trekking, came with a history of rash. Weil Felix test revealed elevated Ox 2 and Ox 19 titers. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Rickettsia Rickettsiae
